header.title: Oto Anorha #29 Aims and Intents: Presencing Falcifer

central_thesis: The document explores the dynamic and evolving nature of the Order of Nine Angles' Sinister Tradition, focusing on its Pantheon of Dark Gods, their historical and etymological context, and the operative mechanics for interacting with these forces. It emphasizes experiential understanding and the continuous development of the system, while also providing a detailed analysis of the historical connections between Baphomet, the Knights Templar, and the star Algol.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces the 29th edition of Oto Anorha, highlighting new discoveries regarding the ONA Dark Gods Pantheon. It details the Temple of THEM's activities, including the establishment of the Black Glyph Society, its aggressive marketing strategy, the re-assembly of ONA materials into books, alliances with Black Light Distribution and Integral Tradition Publishing, and efforts to monopolize Australian distribution of ONA materials. Updates on the Advanced Star Game Project and the exclusive access policy for Mvimaedivm are provided. The section also mentions the abandonment of the 'Naos: The Re-Incarnation' Tarot Deck project due to lack of funding, and explores the 'Hanging Rock' area as a potential Nexion site in Victoria, tying it to local folklore and sinister energies.

structure_content.chapter_title: PANTHEON: A Study of the Dark Gods +o+
structure_content.summary: This part initiates a passive study of the Dark Gods, acknowledging that new discoveries may raise more questions than answers and briefly touching upon the Septenary System. It serves as a prologue, presenting ONA-authored text central to understanding Baphomet and the concept of 'Opfer'. Opfer (sacrifice) is categorized into two types: those for opening nexions/Star Gates and those for maintaining 'cosmic balance', with a third type for death rituals. The 'willing sacrifice' leading to acausal existence is discussed, linking it to ancient Albion traditions and the Ceremony of Recalling as a celebration of Baphomet, the Dark Goddess, represented by the Mistress of Earth. The identification of Baphomet as the Bride of Lucifer/Satan is dated to the 10th-11th century, noting the historical evolution of concepts from earlier Hyperborean aeons where light and sinister aspects were undifferentiated.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Dark Gods (Individual Deities and Concepts)
structure_content.summary: This extensive section provides detailed descriptions of various Dark Gods and related concepts within the ONA tradition. Each entry includes the name, associated paths or properties, traditional meanings, and practical applications (e.g., vibration, key for chant, associated items). Noteworthy entries include: Davcina (female form, 19th path), Bin-Anat/Binan-Ath (Dark female deity, 'Behold the Fire!'), Karu Samsu ('I invoke the Sun', 12th path), Shugara (Ishtar's Helmet, underworld gatekeeper, male deity in ONA), Darkat (lunar goddess, origin of Lilith myth), Lidagon (union of Darkat and Dagon), Nekelah (collective name for Dark Gods), Sapanur (11th path, primal atavism), Gaubni (2nd path, Great Demon, revulsive smell), Budsturga (blue aetherial entity, 13th path, hidden wisdom, dangerous to sanity), Mactoron (14th path, planetary home/star gate), Athushir/Abatu (16th path, serpent of fire/destructive energy), Noctulius (deity of night, 28th name), Vindex (Champion/Avenger, 21st path), Kthunae (Acausal rent, Lovecraft's Nyarlathotep), Ny'thra (energy vortex, terror/destruction), Azanigin (Mother of demons, personal destruction), Sauroctonos (Lizard Slayer), Ga Wath Am ('power within me is great'), Nemicu (Indian/Sumerian deity, demon).

This chapter discusses the diverse origins of the Dark Gods' names, noting that the list in 'Naos' is not a classical pantheon of anthropomorphic deities. Some names are phrases (Karu Samsu, Ga Wath Am), processes (Lidagon), planetary homes (Mactoron), or collective names (Nekelah). It highlights that Naos and Velpecula are constellations and discusses the Sumerian-Mesopotamian roots, local British deities like Aosoth, Norse Mythology (Hel), and Latin influences (Vindex). The chapter addresses the distinction between 'Dark Ones' (androgynous) and 'Dark Gods/Goddesses' (gender specific) and the causal manifestation of these entities. It concludes by emphasizing that the Pantheon, like the Sinister Tradition itself, is a dynamic and evolving 'symbiotic organism,' not a static dogma, continuously shaped by Adepts' experiences and insights rather than being a fixed, ancient tradition.

The Tree of Wyrd is presented as a core symbolic structure resembling Norse Mythology's Nine Worlds of Yggdrasil. It represents the division of cosmic forces into seven fundamental forms of energy, both in the cosmos and the individual, and is a 'map' for attaining 'wisdom' and altering cosmic/individual balance. The Tree also outlines male (Mercury, Sol, Mars) and female (Moon, Venus, Jupiter) aspects, with Saturn 'beyond opposites' (Chaos). Correspondences between Dark Gods are listed (e.g., Mactoron - Ga Wath Am, Baphomet/Darkat - Satan/Lucifer/Phosphorus). The text stresses that the Tree of Wyrd, Pantheon, and Septenary System are 'symbiote concepts' that evolve with understanding and time. It discusses the shift from archetypal symbolism to abstract symbolism (introduced by AL), emphasizing the Tree's representation of causal/acausal duality and the development of consciousness. The ONA's 'Septenary' is a living, accumulating body of esoteric knowledge, with Adepts extending its frontiers. True understanding is gained through practical experience and direct penetration into mysteries, making each Initiate's works unique and authentic.

structure_content.chapter_title: The templar Baphomet and the star Algol
structure_content.summary: Authored by Alektryon Christophoros, this section meticulously details the historical and occult connections between the Baphomet worshipped by the Knights Templar and the star Algol. Drawing from Templar testimonies during the 1307 trials, it describes Baphomet as a fierce, bearded human head, venerated as God and Saviour, believed to bestow riches and fertility. The text then delves into Algol's symbolism, citing historical occult texts that link it to a severed, bloody human head ('The Demon's Head' or 'Ras al-Ghul'), Medusa's head, Lilith, and Rosh ha Satan. It notes the star's astrological reputation as

This concluding part of Alektryon Christophoros's treatise highlights the striking similarities between the Baphomet worshipped by the Templars and the star Algol's symbolic representation. Both are depicted as bearded, demonic, severed heads associated with protection, good luck, fertility, and abundance. The author notes that despite extensive literature on the Templars, the connection to Algol in ceremonial magick has largely been overlooked, deeming this oversight 'incredible' and 'amazing'.

key_concepts.definition: Primordial acausal entities or archetypal energies. Their names are considered approximations to represent their Being. 'Dark Ones' are specified as androgynous, while 'Dark Gods' or 'Goddesses' are gender-specific manifestations, typically understood through causal symbolism until an initiate transcends the Abyss. They are central to the Sinister Tradition's mythos.

The evolving magical and philosophical system of the Order of Nine Angles (ONA). Its core aim is to 'presence Falcifer' through engaging with sinister energies, personal transformation, and the opening of nexions. It is characterized as an organic, symbiotic system, constantly updated by the insights and experiences of its Adepts, rather than a fixed dogma.

A core symbolic framework within the ONA, similar to the Qabalistic Tree of Life, but re-codified by AL. It represents the division of cosmic and individual forces into seven fundamental forms, serving as a 'map' for understanding consciousness, attaining adepthood, and changing cosmic/individual balance. It includes male and female aspects corresponding to planetary spheres, with Saturn beyond these opposites (Chaos). It is explicitly described as a living, symbiotic concept.

A fundamental cosmological duality in ONA thought. The 'causal' refers to consensus reality and the manifest universe, while the 'acausal' represents a realm beyond conventional time and space, where Dark Gods are understood to exist. Magical practices, such as opening nexions, aim to merge or bridge these two realms.

A term generally referring to sacrifice, either symbolic or literal, performed during rituals. It encompasses two primary types: (1) those associated with opening a 'nexion' or 'Star Gate' for 'energy' requirements, and (2) those linked to traditional beliefs about maintaining 'cosmic balance' (e.g., chosen every 17 years for a higher civilization). A third type is for death rituals.

A gateway or point of connection between the causal and acausal realms. Rituals, particularly those involving 'opfer', are performed to open these nexions, allowing acausal energies or Dark Gods to manifest into the causal dimension.

The Dark Goddess, Mistress of Earth, and Bride of Lucifer/Satan within the ONA tradition. Iconography often depicts her as a beautiful woman holding a severed male head. Historically, she is linked to the Templars' veneration of a bearded, fierce head and shares strong symbolic parallels with the star Algol, representing the dark aspect of female energies and a striving toward understanding/conscious integration.

Known as the 'Demon Star' or 'Blinking Demon' ('Ras al-Ghul' meaning 'The Demon's Head'). In ceremonial magic, it is symbolized by a severed, bearded man's head. Astrologically, it's considered an evil star but also associated with protection against evil, good luck, fertility, and abundance. It is strongly linked to the Baphometic idol through shared symbolism of a severed, demonic head.

A central, though implicitly defined, concept within the ONA's 'Aims and Intents.' The explicit goal of the Sinister Tradition and its alliances is to 'presence Falcifer,' implying the manifestation or bringing forth of this sinister force or principle into being.

An alchemical term adopted by the ONA. The name 'Atazoth' (one of the Dark Gods) signifies 'an increasing of azoth,' suggesting a process of energetic potentiation, spiritual transformation, or the intensification of causal-acausal mergence.

A Dark God or 'Dark One' described as an 'acausal rent' or 'chaotic nexion.' It is explicitly identified with Lovecraft's Nyarlathotep, the Messenger, and is said to manifest as a black shadow, silhouette, or a formless chaotic black crack that corrupts the boundaries of reality. Its manifestation is sometimes accompanied by the smell of rotting flesh.

practical_system.description: The ONA's practical system, as described, is an evolving, experiential tradition focused on 'presencing Falcifer' and engaging with 'Sinister Energies' and 'Dark Gods'. It emphasizes individual, direct experience and insight ('penetration into the mysteries') over dogmatic adherence. The core framework is the Septenary System, including the Tree of Wyrd and the Star Game, which serve as symbolic maps for consciousness and cosmic forces. Operative work involves vibrating names, chanting, and performing rituals to open 'nexions' between the causal and acausal realms, aiming for personal transformation and the manifestation of acausal energies.
tools: Sigils (e.g., for Dark Gods, Vindex, Noctulius, Atazoth, Algol)
Vibratory names/chants of Dark Gods (e.g., Karu Samsu, Ga Wath Am)
Crystal tetrahedron (used with Ga Wath Am)
Perfumes/incense (e.g., petriochor for Noctulius, sulphur for Shaitan)
Star Game (used as an abstract symbolic language, with 3D models being developed)
Naos Deck Sinister Tarot (described as a tool for self-understanding and initiation)
Specific musical keys for chants (e.g., A flat major, G Minor, A minor, B Minor, F sharp major)
rituals: Opfer (sacrifice) rituals for opening nexions/Star Gates and maintaining cosmic balance
Black Moon Ordeal (e.g., Sorceress Sor Terrosa for Anima/Animus invocation)
Vibration of names of Dark Gods for specific effects (e.g., Davcina for enchantment, Atazoth for 'increasing azoth', Azanigin for personal destruction)
Chanting specific words of power in designated keys (e.g., Karu Samsu in A flat major, Mactoron in A minor, Noctulius in G Minor)

relevant_quotes.text: The Temple's commission of the Sinister Tarot Deck entitled 'Naos: The Re-Incarnation' [and which was to be featured in this issue of OA] has not received sufficient (i.e. any) external financial support...

It almost goes without saying that over the next five years it will be crucial to form alliances with individuals and organizations whom share our determination and intent to presence Falcifer – and to discard those who do not.

The word 'opfer' generally refers to the sacrifice that occurs - symbolic or otherwise - during certain rituals. There are, generally, two types of opfer: (1) associated with rites to open a nexion (or 'Star Gate'), between Aeons - when such an opfer(s) is considered necessary in terms of the 'energy' required; (2) those associated with traditional beliefs regarding the 'working of the cosmos'.
The cult of Baphomet was the worship of the dark aspect of the "female" energies – where in this context, worship means a striving toward understanding/conscious integration.

The most powerful of the Dark Gods. The name itself (which correctly describes the entity only when chanted properly) signifies in one sense the purpose of the cosmic cycles and the opening of the Gates since 'Atazoth' as a word means 'an increasing of azoth.'

The Sinister Tradition is not a static doctrine and has and will continue, to change as it, and the individuals preserving it, evolve. The Tree of Wyrd, like the Pantheon and most of the Septenary System should be seen in the light of being a symbiote concept - changed and changing over the years in relation to the understanding, time and weltanschauung possessed by its keepers.

In ceremonial magick, the star Algol was symbolized by a severed head, a bearded man's head, with the appearance of a demon; it was said that the head protected against evil, that it brought good-luck, fertility and abundance. Remember that the name ALGOL comes from the Arabian sentence, “Ras al-Ghul”, which means "Demon's Head." The head ("Baphomet”) worshipped by the Knights Templar was also a bearded and demonic head. It was said that it brought good-luck, fertility and abundance, and that it "saved" (that is, protected them against evil).

critical_analysis.relevance: This document offers invaluable insight into the internal workings and foundational philosophy of the Order of Nine Angles (ONA) as of 2008. It clarifies the ONA's unique approach to its Dark Gods Pantheon, emphasizing an experiential, evolving tradition over rigid dogma. The detailed analysis of Baphomet and Algol provides a significant contribution to understanding syncretic occult lineages. For researchers, it contextualizes the ONA's strategic efforts in dissemination and community building. For practitioners, it outlines operative principles, particularly the dynamic nature of their Septenary system and the importance of individual insight.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience comprises existing ONA members, initiates, and affiliates (e.g., Mvimaedivm, Temple of THEM, Sinisterion), serving as an internal update and philosophical guide. A secondary audience includes academic researchers of Western Esotericism and Occultism, particularly those studying modern Satanism or the ONA. The technical depth also appeals to occult practitioners seeking to understand the ONA's specific cosmology and operative magical system.
